comments.text:
the switch from copper coils to superconducting coils also makes a 
difference.

the old massive copper coils used to rapidly heat up, limiting the duration 
of each experiment, and also consumed a lot of energy. with superconducting 
coils it all works much better, once the magnetic fields are up no further 
energy is needed to keep the magnetic fields in place.

plasma volume increases much faster than the surface areas of the magnetic 
fields, while the required intensity of the magnetic fields stays the same.

As an automotive engineer, I can think about one place we can put some of

running out at different rates depending on your opinion. The electric car

the society that we have built. Space is a totally other topic that I won't 
touch because I don't know enough about it.
Now, yes, the fusion reactor is going to be used, predominantly, as a 
research tool. Most of the innovations we have in terms of nuclear physics 
are used for research in their early stages (look at the LHC). I do think 
that fusion is going to be a viable source of much needed energy, as long

comments.text:
+Zer0  Don't get me wrong, I'm not against it. I certainly don't consider 
myself a Luddite. Maybe I lack imagination, but I'm trying to think of  A.) 
applications that would require such extreme energy (except in outer space) 
and B.) The possible unintended consequences of the uses and misuses such 
extreme energy. I might be able to think of a few examples for A, but I 
have no earthly idea about B.

In the last century we have seen major energy use and misuse consequences - 
nuclear weapons and climate change are just two of many examples of the 
consequences of unwise energy use. Of course there have been many many 
benefits to massively increased energy use. but we humans have no 
underlying philosophical foundations for the energy we use. We say to 
ourselves "WOW, TEN TIMES HOTTER THAN THE SUN. COOL!!" without thinking at 
all of what all the implications such energy production and use brings or 
might bring with it.

As we move into this new epoch / evolution, we, as a species, need to have 
a well grounded dialog about where we want to go and how we want to get 
there.

top_comment.text:
Tokamak will fail for the very reason stated in this video: it uses 
electromagnets to squeeze atomic nuclei together, and electromagnatism 
requires energy -- enough energy to exceed the output of the fusion 
process.  Also, Tokamak will fuse tritium and deuterium together, and not 
regular hydrogen.  The "energy" generated will be in the form of free 
neutrons that exit the reactor's magnetic field. Freed neutrons will heat 
the carbon walls of the reactor.  The  Sun produces gamma photons from 
simple hydrogen being fused to form helium.  It's a totally different 
process, and that is a good thing, because fusion of hydrogen into helium 
is about as non-renewable as energy production gets!  If simple hydrogen 
could be turned into helium, then we'd eventually have nothing but blue 
skies and no water, after we'd wrung Earth of all of its life giving 
hydrogen.﻿

comments.text:
+ShamWerks Ya, there is thorium like mentioned above and there are reactors 
that can burn natural uranium.  And there is also a near limitless supply 
of uranium in the ocean, enough to power the world at western standards for 
a very, very long time (something like 10k years if I remember the math).  

Lasse is slightly mistaken about the waste generation, there are activated 
radioactive materials in a fusion reactor that will have to disposed of 
carefully.  And depending on how you do the fusion process, there might be 
waste products in the form of tritium from incomplete fusion (like in 
inertial confinement fusion targets).  Both fusion and fission have more 
manageable waste streams, however, than fossil fuels, so I see the fear 
over nuclear waste vs fossil fuel waste a real misnomer.  People should be 
much more concerned with ash slurry ponds constructed out of necessity and 
near rivers and communities rather than geological isolation sites designed 
with purpose and away from population centers.  But I will leave that rant 
for another day :D

Well, most of the energy from this reaction is in the form of neutrons 
(deuterium tritium fusion) . They fly away from the plasma because the are 
electrically neutral the magnetic confinement does not affect them. The 
neutrons heat up the wall of the tokamak which in turn heats water spinning 
a turbine. Needless to say there is no way to stop radioactivity only a way 
to contain it. The problem with tokamaks is not the obvious radioactivity 
it is making any amount of usable energy. There is no immense gravity field 
squashing everything together. To counteract the lack of gravity you need A 
LOT more heat; so much heat that there is no net gain in energy making the 
fusion reaction a neat science experiment, but nothing more. The one that 
figures out how to achieve net fusion is the worlds first trillionaire.

comments.text:
So, gonna say things here.

Have you ever heard of micro evolution? It's something that's been proven 
in labs countless times. They take animals with very short breeding cycles, 
such as flies, and find genetic traits that are expressed visually. Things 
like different wing colors and such. (The exact example I use may not be 
accurate, but the general idea is still the same, for those of you who may 
wish to nitpick me.)

They then take the flies, or whatever they're using, that express these 
genetic traits, and isolate them. Then, they let them breed. Continue this 
process, removing any organisms that contain undesired traits, and 
eventually the isolated population produces only the trait that was 
isolated without any contamination of other traits that may change the wing 
color, or whatever else is being isolated.

This is micro evolution, the whole 'natural selection' thing, where 
undesireble traits which hinder the survival of the species are, gradually, 
removed.

Now, another thing. You've probably heard of genetic mutations, yes? Things 
like autism, down syndrome, all these things that happen at birth? Well, 
those are caused by the same broad event that allows us to have so many 
hair colors, eye colors, and even different species. Genetic mutations.

Many genetic mutations are bad. However, there are also many that are 
either harmless or even beneficial. It could be compared to throwing bouncy 
balls at a wall with a cup behind you. Throw enough - might be hundreds, 
thousands, millions - and one will eventually land in the cup. The ones 
that miss are the mutations that either do nothing, or mess things up. The 
ones that land in the cup are the beneficial ones that help the carriers of 
the trait survive more effectively, even in a minute manner.

Now, I've told you about micro evolution, and genetic mutations, and how 
genetic mutations can, effectively, cause micro evolution. The evolutionary 
theory, however, as my miniscule understanding of it can tell, deals mainly 
in macro evolution.

Macro evolution is these two things, plus a whole fuck-load of time. We're 
talking, not hundreds, not thousands, but hundreds of thousand, if not 
millions, of years. Small trait changes happen via genetic mutation. Many, 
many, many, MAAAANY, instances of micro evolution and natural selection 
spread them around. This is what causes macro evolution.

The evidence of this can be found in the fossil record and the view into 
many transitional species, in the way DNA is replicated, in the way that 
the flies function in the lab, even in the exchange of DNA between 
bacteria. Literally, the evidence for the evolutionary theory is all around 
you. It plays a part in your day-to-day life.

Provided you read all that, can you really say that "they is a complete 
retard" anymore?
comments.author: ReadeDraconis

comments.author: Dylan Woessner

comments.text:
+rcbif101   Ahh you are dead on with that statement.  :) ferromagnetic 
materials do maintain their magnetic charge for a time.  In some cases, a 
very long time.  A very similar martial is used in your computer hard 
drive, and allows it to 'save' information (positive charge/negative charge 
ie 1's and 0's) even after the power is gone.  Which is why running a 
magnet over your computer hard drive can damage the data...it changes the 
magnetic state of the bits.

It's not so much about creating a magnet or a magnetic material, it's about 
generating a magnetic field with varying power in a way that you can 
control.

In the video, Hank mentioned that the steel will be shaped into loops to 
make massive magnetic coils.  The shape is what's important here.  He's 
describing an electromagnetic coil, where a conductor (steel) is wound 
around a core or form to create an inductor or electromagnet.  When 
electricity is passed threw the coil, it generates a magnetic field.  The 
advantage is, you can have a magnet that varies in power based on how much 
electricity you feed it.  A natural magnet cannot produce anything close to 
the power an electromagnet can, and we can't change a natural magnets state 
(well we can..it's a pain) to suit our needs.

And in order to have a good and efficient electromagnet, it's best if you 
start with a material that doesn't generate it's own magnetic field, but 
can hold one very well.
comments.author: Jed Shenefelt

comments.text:
+Jed Shenefelt
Would ferritic stainless hold any noticible magnetic field like carbon 
steel if stroked with a magnet for a while? It's still not magnetic as most 
carbon steels, right? I was aware of ferritic stainless, I would have just 
figured something that is more magnetic would be better.
comments.author: Rcbif

comments.text:
Austenitic Stainless steel is non magnetic. and that's probably what you're 
thinking about. The type of steel they're using here is most likely going 
to be Ferritic stainless steel.  The difference is hard to explain, but 
basically the magnetic domains in its micro-structure are designed to be 
Ferraro-magnetic.  meaning that they will not produce a magnetic field, but 
will tend to hold one if an external magnet field is applied.
comments.author: Jed Shenefelt

captions.text: Who’s in the mood for some good news?

Yeah, when we talk about all the changes taking
place on Earth, we usually wind up talking

about living things that are endangered, threatened,
or even extinct.

But science is always giving us lots of discoveries
of new kinds of life as well.

To remind us that we’re still finding new
organisms all over the planet, even as others

are disappearing, every year the International
Institute for Species Exploration issues its
Top 10 New Species list.

On Thursday it released its roster of the
most interesting species discovered in 2014,

and they range from the pesky to the huge
to the adorable.

I’m assuming you want to see the adorable,
so let’s start there.

Well, we’ve told you before about the olinguito
-- it looks like a cross between a raccoon

and a teddy bear -- and it’s the first mammal
to be discovered in the Americas in 35 years.

It was only confirmed in the wild last summer,
found in the cloud forests of Ecuador and
Colombia.

But it turns out that, for the past century
or so, some olinguitos had been mistakenly

displayed in museums, and even zoos, as their
larger relatives, olingos.

It was only after a DNA comparison, and many
reports of strange, little olingos acting

weird in zoos, that biologists confirmed it
was a whole different animal.

Plants, too, made this year’s list, but
none can rival the size -- or the awesome
name -- of the Kaweesak’s Dragon Tree.

Hard to imagine it’s gone overlooked for
so long, since the dragon tree grows up to

12 meters tall and sports a crown 12 meters
wide, with leaves shaped like sword blades.

But it grows only on limestone hills in parts
of Burma and Thailand, and there are only
about 2,500 of them known to exist.

What’s more, biologists say the dragon tree
is endangered because the limestone it grows

on is rapidly being extracted to be used for
concrete.

And one surprise on the list is an organism
that was found growing in probably one of

the only place on Earth where we absolutely
do not want anything but us to live.

The new bacterium known as Tersicoccus phoenicis
was found growing in two different clean rooms

where NASA’s Phoenix Lander is being assembled
-- one in Florida and the other in French
Guiana. Yes, it was named after a Mars lander.

We make spacecraft in these hyper-sanitized
clean rooms because we don’t want to contaminate

the other worlds we send them to -- in this
case, the Phoenix will be going to Mars -- and

we don’t wanna muck up the experiments that
we conduct to test for alien life.

But sure enough, these germs survived multiple
rounds of chemical cleansers and UV sterilization,

giving us new insights into the extreme environments
that life can survive in.

You can check out the rest of the IISE’s
Top 10 List in the links below.

But now let’s get ready to talk about something
really huge: last week, work finally began

on key components of the world’s first experimental
fusion reactor.

It’s called ITER, the International Thermonuclear
Experimental Reactor, and it will weigh 23

thousand tons, and take up about 60 soccer
fields worth of space in southern France.

By the time it’s ready to go online in 2025,
it’ll have more than ten million parts...including

80,000 kilometers of superconducting filaments,
to power its immense magnets.

This thing is going to rival one of my favorite
pieces of hardware -- the Large Hadron Collider

-- for the title of ‘most complicated machine
ever built.’

ITER’s ultimate aim is to generate energy
the same way the Sun does: by fusing hydrogen
atoms to make helium.

It’s going to try to do it by using a magnetic
field to contain superheated plasma in a doughnut-shaped
reactor called a tokamak.

So sounds simple enough…why does it need
to weigh as much as three Eiffel Towers?

Well, the Sun has a lot going for it, other
than super-high temperatures, when it comes
to causing fusion. It’s got all that gravity.

But we cannot replicate that gravity on Earth,
so our plasma needs to be that much hotter
in order to compensate.

The core of the Sun is about fifteen million
degrees Celsius.

The ITER tokamak is going to be ten times
hotter. TEN TIMES HOTTER THAN THE CORE OF
THE SUN!

And right now, in the French Riviera, the
magnets that are going to power this thing

are being manufactured. They’re made of
massive loops of high-grade stainless steel.

Seven of these things stacked on top of each
other will make one magnetic coil, and will
weigh about as much as a 747.

Many believe that fusion power is the world’s
best hope for clean and plentiful energy;

but others say that ITER will just end up
costing 20 billion dollars and being a neato

science experiment but not actually helping
with the energy crisis…

Remind me to follow up with you about this
in 11 years or so.

In the meantime, thank you for watching SciShow
News! If you want to keep learning more about

the world with us, you can help us by going
to subbable.com and becoming a contributing
member.

And if you want to keep getting smarter with
us, you can just go to youtube.com/scishow
and subscribe!

title: Top 10 New Species and the First Fusion Reactor
